unnormalised: The year was 2010. My father, R.K. Sharma, a retired schoolteacher, was always a cautious man. He’d saved diligently his entire life, but never really ventured beyond fixed deposits in SBI. Then, a slick insurance agent convinced him to invest in a ULIP, promising fantastic returns linked to the market. The policy, Jeevan Suraksha Plus, sounded impressive, but the fine print… well, that was another story. He invested Rs. 50,000 annually.
normalised: The year was two thousand and ten. My father, R-K Sharma, a retired schoolteacher, was always a cautious man. He'd saved diligently his entire life, but never really ventured beyond fixed deposits in S-B-I. Then, a slick insurance agent convinced him to invest in a U-L-I-P, promising fantastic returns linked to the market. The policy, Jeevan Suraksha Plus, sounded impressive, but the fine print… well, that was another story. He invested rupee fifty thousand annually.

unnormalised: For the first few years, everything seemed fine. The market was doing well, and the policy statements showed a healthy growth. He’d even brag about it to his friends over chai at the local tea stall. Then came 2014. The market tanked, and with it, a significant chunk of his investment. He showed me the statement; a depressing dip of almost 20%. He started losing sleep, worrying about his hard-earned savings.
normalised: For the first few years, everything seemed fine. The market was doing well, and the policy statements showed a healthy growth. He'd even brag about it to his friends over chai at the local tea stall. Then came two thousand and fourteen. The market tanked, and with it, a significant chunk of his investment. He showed me the statement; a depressing dip of almost twenty percent. He started losing sleep, worrying about his hard-earned savings.

unnormalised: He considered surrendering the policy, but the agent, always quick to reassure, advised against it. “Just hold on, Sharmaji,” he’d say. “The market will recover.” He continued to pay the premium, Rs 50,000/yr, hoping for the best. But the market remained volatile, and the charges associated with the policy kept eating into his returns. He consulted a financial advisor, Mr. Gupta, who told him the policy had high management fees of 2.5%/yr.
normalised: He considered surrendering the policy, but the agent, always quick to reassure, advised against it. “Just hold on, Sharmaji,” he'd say. “The market will recover.” He continued to pay the premium, rupee fifty thousand per year, hoping for the best. But the market remained volatile, and the charges associated with the policy kept eating into his returns. He consulted a financial advisor, Mister Gupta, who told him the policy had high management fees of two point five percent per year.

unnormalised: Then, in 2020, he was diagnosed with a heart condition. The medical bills started piling up. We needed the money. He decided to finally surrender the policy. After all those years, after investing Rs. 5 lakhs (5,00,000), he received a paltry sum of Rs. 3.8 lakhs. The insurance agent was nowhere to be found. We later found out that the agent had earned a hefty commission of ~10% on the initial premium.
normalised: Then, in two thousand and twenty, he was diagnosed with a heart condition. The medical bills started piling up. We needed the money. He decided to finally surrender the policy. After all those years, after investing rupee five lakhs (five hundred thousand), he received a paltry sum of rupee three point eight lakhs. The insurance agent was nowhere to be found. We later found out that the agent had earned a hefty commission of approximately ten percent on the initial premium.

unnormalised: The experience taught us a valuable lesson about insurance policies. Not all that glitters is gold. It’s essential to understand the fine print, the associated charges, and the market risks involved. My father, ever the optimist, took it in stride. "It's alright beta," he said. "At least we learned something". He even jokingly said, "Next time, I'll stick to FD’s!".

"At least we learned something". He even jokingly said, "Next time, I'll stick to F-D’s!".

unnormalised: Now, I always research thoroughly before investing in any insurance policy, reading the policy document multiple times and comparing different options. I make sure to check the expense ratios and understand the surrender charges before committing. It’s a lesson etched in my memory, a reminder of my father's hard-earned money and the importance of financial literacy. So, always do your homework before signing on the dotted line for any insurance policy, whether it's for life insurance, health insurance, or vehicle insurance. Learn from Sharmaji’s story.
